text:
On Friday, Taylor Swift released a teaser for the video for her new single "Look What You Made Me Do." Some Twitter users noticed similarities between the clip and Beyoncé's Lemonade visual album, accusing Taylor of cultural appropriation. They pointed toward a scene where Taylor's wearing a black leotard and standing flanked by male backup dancers in a mansion, which they compared to a scene from Beyoncé's "Formation" video, Buzzfeed reports.

Joseph Kahn, the director of the "Look What You Made Me Do" video, responded to the accusations in a tweet on Friday. "I’ve worked with Beyoncé a few times. She’s an amazing person. The #LWYMMDvideo is not in her art space. Love and respect to Bey," he wrote. Kahn's likely referring to his work with Destiny Child on their "Say My Name" and "Jumpin’ Jumpin" videos. He's also directed a number of other Taylor Swift videos, including the one for "Bad Blood," Just Jared Jr. reports.

The entire "Look What You Made Me Do" video will premiere Sunday at the VMAs. Taylor Swift and Beyoncé haven't commented on the comparisons.

Related: Taylor Swift's Label Responds to Accusations of Shading Kanye With Her Album

title: Taylor Swift Video Director Responds to Accusations of Copying Beyoncé

meta_data.author: Condé Nast
